Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Kisspeptin Regulation of Reproductive Physiology of a Coral Reef Fish
Award.AbstractNarration: Despite decades of research, major questions remain about how environmental cues control the vertebrate reproductive system. The list of key biochemical "gatekeepers" for activation of the reproductive system from fishes to humans includes two important protein hormones, Gonadotropin-releasing hormone and kisspeptin, that function in the brain. This project would investigate how social cues affect these hormones in the brain of an animal model system that is particularly powerful for revealing connections between the social environment and the reproductive system. This animal model is the bluehead wrasse (Thalassoma bifasciatum), a fish species that has been the subject of many foundational studies of environmental influences on reproductive function. This project will use molecular neurobiology methods to map the gonadotropin-releasing hormone and kisspeptin signaling systems in the brain of the bluehead wrasse, in order to compare the expression of these hormones across different reproductive phases, and to test the effects of manipulating these hormones on reproductive function. A key element of the project is to provide undergraduates from North Carolina State University and Indian River State College in Florida with experience in behavioral field studies and molecular biological laboratory studies. A second benefit will be an increased understanding of the control of reproduction in fishes because the bluehead wrasse is a particularly useful animal for understanding the specific mechanisms of this control. This knowledge is valuable to the aquaculture industry because the control of reproduction represents a key barrier to the propagation of fishes in captivity. Finally, this project will lead to the development of educational materials focused on Florida marine environments in collaboration with the Center for Ocean Science Education Excellence. Gene sequences will be archived in Genbank and cDNAs will be provided to interested parties on a cost-of-transport basis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the hormonal correlates of reproductive function in a hermaphroditic coral reef fish whose physiology is strongly responsive to social cues.  This fish is the bluehead wrasse and we studied its biology on reefs near Key Largo, Florida with graduate and undergraduate students from North Carolina State University and undergraduate students from Indian River State College. These studies entailed manipulating the social environment of bluehead wrasses on coral patch reefs to create the conditions that induce sex change, observing the behavioral changes that occur in this process, then recapturing the fish after varying degrees of progress through the sex change process to examine the expression of genes in their brains. The major focus of the gene expression studies was in elucidating the potential role of peptides termed 'kisspeptins' in sex change as these peptides play critical roles in mammalian reproduction. The key findings were that bluehead wrasses have two forms of the kisspeptin gene and that one of these is much more highly expressed in a key brain area (the ventral hypothalamus) regulating reproduction in large males than in females, although this increase in expression does not appear to occur until late in the sex change process. Attempts to induce sex change through manipulations of kisspeptin signaling were not successful. We also found that receptors for kisspeptins are widely expressed in the brain of this species, including in or close to brain areas expressing other protein hormones we know are key regulators of behavior and reproductive function.  Lastly, we found that expression of a kisspeptin gene and some other key regulators of reproduction and behavior vary in a tidal rather than circadian pattern, increasing as the daytime high tide approaches when the fish exhibit reproduction and reproductive behavior.  This has not been demonstrated in other animals. More generally, this work builds on a growing understanding of how social and other environmental cues are 'translated' into important changes in the brain and reproductive axis in animals, particularly the involvement of the kisspeptin group of peptides that are key regulators of reproductive function across vertebrates.

The broader impacts of this project were primarily in the training and providing of integrative research experiences to undergraduate and graduate students from North Carolina State University (NCSU) and Indian River State College (IRSC).  This project was the foundation for the research projects of two graduate students at North Carolina State University and also supported the involvement of six undergraduate students from NCSU.  Eight undergraduate students from Indian River State College participated in the research project as well.  This was an integrative experience because the students gained experience in both field experiments in Florida and learned techniques for measuring gene expression in the brain samples they gathered in the laboratory at NCSU. Additionally, all students participated in either graduate or undergraduate research symposia where they presented their findings publicly.  Additional broader impact activities included public outreach presentations of the research project to various audiences including middle and high schoolers, senior living residents, and several 'Brain Awareness' events in North Carolina. The project was also the subject of a public  television program in the 'Our Changing Seas' series produced by Miami PBS affiliate WPBT.
